sub_topic: Length contraction in a moving frame of reference
message_1: A spaceship is travelling at a velocity of 0.8c (where c is the speed of light) with respect to Earth. The length of the spaceship in its own frame of reference is 60 meters. Calculate the length of the spaceship as seen by an observer on Earth.
message_2:
To calculate the length of the spaceship as seen by an observer on Earth, we need to use the concept of length contraction in special relativity. The formula for length contraction is:

L = L0 * sqrt(1 - v^2 / c^2)

where L is the contracted length as seen by the observer on Earth, L0 is the proper length of the spaceship in its own frame of reference (60 meters), v is the relative velocity of the spaceship (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

L = 60 * sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2 / c^2)

L = 60 * sqrt(1 - 0.64)

L = 60 * sqrt(0.36)

L = 60 * 0.6

L = 36 meters

So, the length of the spaceship as seen by an observer on Earth is 36 meters.
